Description: Wooden foot-stool leg: originally painted, this was probably from the front of a low foot stool. It is notched at the back.
Curator's comments: The style of carving of the ruff-like mane, open roaring mouth, wrinkles under the eyes and curling line rendering of musculature on the shoulder are characteristic of Persian-period depictions of lions from Egypt, and places this piece within the period of the Achaemenid empire. A small number of other carved wooden objects of this period are known, including a recumbent lion box lid which passed through various collections from 1905 onwards (Christie's Antiquities sale, London 7 October 2010, lot 22).
Bibliographic references: Simpson 1996a / An Achaemenid furniture leg from Egypt
Curtis & Tallis 2005 / Forgotten Empire: The world of Ancient Persia (cat. 93, p. 101)
Exhibition history: Exhibited: 2006 7 Mar-11 Jun, Barcelona, Fundacion La Caixa, 'L'imperi Oblidat' 2005-2006 Sept-Jan, London, BM, 'Forgotten Empire' G52/IRAN/8, from 1996.
Funder name: Funded by: British Museum Friends (as British Museum Society)
Previous owner: Previous owner/ex-collection: Dr Daniel Marie Fouquet
Acquisition notes: Christie's sale of 3rd July 1996, lot 245, where illustrated and described as "An Egypto-Persian wooden chair leg in the form of the forepart of a lion. Circa 525-404 B.C. Snarling with mouth agape and an 'apron' hanging down below its mane, morticed at the back. 9in (23cm.) high. Estimate: £2,000-2,500". Previously sold through the Hôtel Drouot in Paris in 1922 and previously in the collection of M. Daniel Marie Fouquet.
